questions.question: Everybody ............................. wear seat belts.
questions.description: We use should to talk about obligation. Would is not possible with this meaning.

questions.question: When we were kids, we ................................ spend hours playing football.
questions.description: To talk about past habits, we use 'would'.

questions.question: I told them we ................................ probably be late.
questions.description: In British English, with the first person pronouns I and we both would and should can be used to express simple futurity. Note that should is not normally used with this meaning in American English.

questions.question: We ................................ be grateful for an early reply.
questions.description: In British English, with the first person pronouns I and we both would and should can be used to express simple futurity. Note that should is not normally used with this meaning in American English.

questions.question: People ............................... drive more carefully.
questions.description: To express obligation, we use should.

questions.question: ............................ you like something to eat?
questions.description: In polite offers and requests, we use 'would', not 'should'.

questions.question: You ............................... not have called him a fool - it really upset him.
questions.description: We use 'should not have ' to refer to unwanted things that happened.

questions.question: I knew that I ............................ write to her, but it seemed too difficult.
questions.description: We use 'should' to talk about obligations.

questions.question: ............................. we call the police?
questions.description: In questions, should is used to ask for advice or instructions.

questions.question: I wish you ................................... behave like this?
questions.description: We use 'wish + would' to express ideas such as dissatisfaction or irritation.
